column2: Once the home front was secured, Hitler turned his attention to foreign policy with four increasingly daring acts.  On the 16th of March 1935, the Treaty of Versailles was violated by Germany as military conscription was reintroduced.  The treaty stated that the German Army should not exceed 100,000 men.\n When nothing more than official protests from England and France followed, Hitler proceeded, a year later on 7 March 1936, to occupy the demilitarised Rhineland, again violating the Versailles Treaty.

Demands for the union (Anschluss) of Austria and Germany increased after Adolf Hitler became German Chancellor.  In February 1938, Hitler invited Kurt von Schuschnigg, the Austrian Chancellor, to meet him at Berchtesgaden.  Hitler demanded concessions for the Austrian Nazi Party.  Schuschnigg refused and on 9th March 1938, the Austrian Chancellor announced a plebiscite (referendum) on the independence of Austria.\n Adolf Hitler took this as an opportunity to take action against the Austrian State.  Schuschnigg was pressed to resign.  The National Socialist Arthur Seyss-Inquart took over the chancellorship and formed a new government.  The Austrian National Socialists took power in Austria.\n  On the morning of 12 March 1938, troops of the German Wehrmacht and the SS crossed the German-Austrian border.  On 13 March 1938, Hitler, in Linz announced the passage of the "Anschluss" (Annexation) of Austria into the German Reich.

During the summer of 1938 the pro-Nazi elements among the Czech-Germans demanded the right to secede from Czechoslovakia.  A move that created enormous tension between Germany and Czechoslovakia.  Hitler, using the minority sentiments in the Sudetenland started to propagandize about "Czech Atrocities" against ethnic Germans in an effort to lay the blame for a future conflict on the Czech government.  At the same time", as German troops infiltrated the Bohemian borderlands, Hitler agreed to host a Peace Conference in Munich.\nHitler, Chamberlain, Daladier, and Mussolini met and agreed that Hitler should have the Sudetenland of Czechoslovakia.  The Czechs, who were not represented at the meeting, realised that their own allies were deserting them and under pressure from the French and British, they were forced to surrender the Sudetenland to Germany.\n Hitler assured those at the meeting that this was the extent of his ambitions for expansion.  Chamberlain returned to England with a piece of paper signed by Hitler proclaiming "peace in our time."

The Vienna Award was a diplomatic attempt by Germany and Italy to enforce Hungary's claims to the southern parts of Carpathian Rus and Slovakia, at that time a part of Czechoslovakia.  Negotiations started in October 1938, but despite intense negotiations, no satisfactory solution acceptable for both parties was to be found.\nIn November, Hungarian forces began to cross the border into the territory and only a few months later, Hitler gave Hungary his permission to annex the remaining lands of Carpathian Rus, thus reestablishing the historic borders between Hungary and Poland.

After the swallowing of the Sudetenland, Hitler used a small group of Slovakian patriots around Tiso more or less forcing them to proclaim an independent Slovakia.  At the same time German troops started to move across the Czechoslovakian border on the pretext of "protecting" the Slovak people. Swiftly demanding the Czech president come to Germany to discuss recent "Czech problems" Hitler managed to isolate and threaten the Czech leader into submission.  A few days later the German Army had full control of the former Czechoslovakia.
On 22nd March 1939 after immense pressure and with German forces ready to attack, the Lithuanian government agreed to give Memel (Klaipeda) to Germany and to sign a non-aggression pact.

Ribbentrop asked the Poles for the return of Danzig and a strip of German territory across the Polish corridor on which a German-run road and rail link could be built.  This time Hitler met real resistance.  On 31 March 1939 the British and French guaranteed the borders of Poland.  Encouraged by the guarantee, the Poles were not about to compromise.\n Then, as 1939 progressed, the position of the Soviet Union became critical.  If Stalin allied himself with Britain, Germany would run the risk of a two-front war if she pushed the world toward conflict.  British attempts at negotiation with the Soviet Union were, however, lacklustre.  For both ideological and practical reasons Stalin had purged thousands of officers from the Red Army and the Soviets were perceived to be a third-rate military force.  Stalin was also unwilling to be pushed into a war which offered him little in terms of his own narrow self-interest.\n Then the Nazis pulled what Manfred von Schröder calls a stroke of courage and genius."  They signed their own treaty with the Soviet Union", their greatest ideological enemy.

Marco Polo Bridge - Teach the Chinese

Japanese garrison troops in Feng-Tai, southwest of Beiping, clashed with Chinese forces at the Marco Polo Bridge.  The battle was at first limited to a local conflict and some hurried negotiations restored order.  But soon thereafter new incidents flared up and Japanese forces began offensive operations.

On August 23, 1939 Hitler and Stalin signed a non-aggression pact, called the Molotov-Ribbentrop Treaty.  Secret protocols of the treaty defined the territorial spheres of influence Germany and Russia would have after a successful invasion of Poland.  Hitler had been creating justifications and laying plans for such an invasion since April.  According to the agreement, Russia would have control over Latvia, Estonia, and Finland, while Germany would gain control over Lithuania and Danzig.\n Poland would be partitioned into three major areas.  The Warthland area, bordering Germany would be annexed outright to the German Reich, and all non-German inhabitants expelled to the east. Over 77,000 square miles of eastern Polish lands, with a population of over thirteen million would become Russian territory.  The central area would become a German protectorate, named the General Government, governed by a German civil authority.

On the 27th of June 1940, Romania bowed to a Russian ultimatum demanding the immediate cession not only of Bessarabia but also of the northern part of the Bukovina.  That area had never formally been ceded to Romania and was thus claimed for the USSR’s sphere of influence in the agreement with Hitler.
Deliver Ultimatum to the Baltic States

During the summer of 1940 the Soviet Union began making preparations for a total takeover of the Baltic States.  According to the non-aggression pact signed by Hitler and Stalin the previous year, the Soviets would get control over Latvia, Estonia and Finland, while Germany would focus on Danzig and Lithuania.  On the 15th of June, an ultimatum was delivered to Lithuania, and just a few days later similar terms were presented to Latvia and Estonia.

On September 2nd,1940, the governments of the United States and the United Kingdom reached an agreement for the transfer of 50 destroyers of the 1200 type from the US Navy to the Royal Navy, in return for American basing rights for 99 years in the Carribean, Guiana, Newfoundland, Bermuda and elsewhere.

The Lend-Lease Agreements were arrangements for the transfer of war supplies, including food, machinery, and services, to nations whose defence was considered vital to the defence of the United States in World War II.  The Lend-Lease Act, passed in 1941 by the U.S. Congress, gave the President power to sell, transfer, lend or lease such war materials.  The President was directed to set the terms for aid repayment to be "in kind or property" or any other direct or indirect benefit which the President deems satisfactory."

Harry L. Hopkins was appointed in March", 1941 to administer lend-lease.  He was replaced in July by Edward R. Stettinius, Jr., who headed the Office of Lend-Lease Administration, set up in Oct., 1941.  In Sept.,1943, lend-lease was incorporated into the Foreign Economic Administration under Leo T. Crowley.  In Sept.,1945, it was transferred to the Dept. of State.
 Lend-lease was originally intended for China and countries of the British Empire.  In Nov.,1941, the USSR was included, and by the end of the war practically all the allies of the United States had been declared eligible for lend-lease aid.  Although not all requested or received it, lend-lease agreements were signed with numerous countries.

After the German occupation of Denmark in April 1940 British forces swiftly took possession of Iceland to counter a possible threat of a German invasion.  Britain held it with few forces and in early 1941 it was evident that it would be better if the United States took over the watch-keeping.  By the summer of 1941, U. S. troops occupied both Greenland and Iceland in the North Atlantic.\n\nThe U. S. occupation of Greenland was arranged through an agreement between the United States government and a rebellious Danish Ambassador in Washington.  This Danish Ambassador refused to recognize or obey the Danish government in Copenhagen after the German occupation of Denmark, which began in April of 1940.  The Greenland Agreement, signed in April of 1941, encountered vigorous protests from both the Danish government and the German Embassy in Washington.

During the 1930's Stalin’s paranoia had increased and numerous power struggles between lesser men were viewed as dangerous to his leadership.  In a wave of three major and a dozen smaller purges the political and military leadership of the Soviet Union was effectively decimated and put under Stalin's strict control.\n The purge of the army eliminated 3 of the 5 marshals, 14 of the 16 army commanders, and approximately half of the 70 to 80,000 men in the entire officer corps.  Needless to say, this purge inevitably had an extremely destructive effect on the effectiveness of the Red Army's military leadership.
Transfer Some of the Industry to Siberia

When the onslaught by the Germans began, Soviet army groups in the west were quickly overrun and the remainder of the Red Army had to rapidly devise a plan for defense.  Soviet leadership decided that the Red Army had to slow down the German advance and force their armies to spread out as thinly as possible.  This would make it possible to launch a counter-offensive during the next year.\n It was also decided that this plan would buy the Soviets time to dismantle heavy industry facilities in the west and move them to Siberia in order to maintain production.

After the Fall of France and the installation of a pro-German government at Vichy Japan was able to profit from the new political situation in South-East Asia and occupy French Indochina under the argument that it "protected" this area from the British.

Italy delivered Tiranë an ultimatum on March 25,1939, demanding that it accede to Italy's occupation of Albania.  King Zog refused to accept money in exchange for countenancing a full Italian takeover and colonization of Albania, and on April 7,1939, Mussolini's troops invaded Albania.  Despite some stubborn resistance, especially at Durrës, the Italians made short shrift of the Albanians.\n Unwilling to become an Italian puppet, King Zog, his wife, Queen Geraldine Apponyi, and their infant son, Skander fled to Greece and eventually to London.  On April 12, the Albanian parliament voted to unite the country with Italy.  Victor Emmanuel III took the Albanian crown, and the Italians set up a fascist government under Shefqet Verlaci and soon absorbed Albania's military and diplomatic services into Italy's.
The Second Vienna Award - Claim Transylvania

Transylvania was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire until after World War I, when the Treaty of Trianon reduced Hungary to one third of its former size and lowered the population by three-fifths.  Transylvania became part of the newly formed Romania.  Admiral Horthy of Hungary demanded that the borders be redrawn and in 1940 he got his way in the "Vienna Diktat" which gave northern Transylvania back to Hungary.

On September 7, 1940, the Treaty of Craiova was signed between Romania and Bulgaria.  Romania did so reluctantly and only under pressure from Hitler's regime.  The Romanians had to cede the southern part of the Dobrogea area which they had captured in the Second Balkan War, as well as participate in a population transfer of ethnic Romanians from the territory.

In early 1936, after the electoral victory of the Socialists, popular demands for social equality evolved into a virtual revolution against the clergy, landowners, and monarchists.  Mobs attacked churches and tried to collectivise farms.  Unions started strikes and anarchists assassinated enemies of the people."  The newly installed government was unable to restore order.\n The Spanish army joined the Conservatives and Catholics to put down the social revolution and they thus styled themselves" the "Nationalists."  The government facing an army rebellion styled themselves "Republicans" and decided to fight", joining in with the forces of revolution.\n The Spanish Civil War had begun!  Many countries like Germany, Italy and the Soviet Union intervened with forces in the conflict.

The non-aggression pact between Germany and Russia in August 1939 turned many heads in Finland.  Germany agreed to give the Baltic States, including Finland, to Russia.  Of course, all this was kept a secret, but as time went on, the events became known to the Finns.\n As Russian aggression grew, the Finns requested help from Germany, only to be turned away - leaving the Finns to face Russia's aggression alone.  When Finland refused to allow the Soviet Union to build military bases on its territory, the latter revoked the nonaggression pact of 1932 and attacked Finland on 30 November 1939.\n The Winter War ended in a peace treaty drawn up in Moscow on the 13th of March,1940, giving south-eastern Finland to the Soviet Union.
Send Volunteers and Materiel to Finland

When Finland was attacked by the Soviet Union, the Swedish government splintered along three lines.  One line of activists including the leader of the Conservative Party Gösta Bagge and the Social Democratic Foreign Minister Richard Sandler promoted direct military intervention.  A second middle-ground line supported by the Prime Minister Per Albin Hansson urged indirect support and neutrality.  The last line represented by Minister of Finance Ernst Wigforss urged strict neutrality and avoidance of war against a fellow socialist country.\n A heated debate commenced and in the end the middle-ground line was chosen as the basis for Swedish foreign policy.

In July 1940 the British initiated "Operation Catapult."  Despite their alliance with France", the United Kingdom made the decision to attack the French fleet stationed at Mers-el-Kébir, Algeria.  France had just signed an armistice with Germany and the possibility of the Germans taking control of those ships was considered too much of a risk to leave unattended.

The fall of France and the growing power of the Axis offers a perfect opportunity to pressure Siam into joining our expansive alliance.  Siam lost control of Laos and Cambodia to France in 1893 and was forced to cede parts of the Malacca peninsula to Britain in 1909.  With a little prodding, they should prove eager to avenge these losses.
All of China must unite and stand together against Soviet aggression.  We will not let these barbarian hordes overrun us while we are divided!

In October 1940, Mussolini and his ministers began making plans for a future invasion of Greece.  On the 28th an ultimatum was presented to the Greeks.  Ioannis Metaxas, the Greek Prime Minister at the time, decided that war was the only option, and shortly after, Italian troops launched their first attack from Albania, and so the Greco-Italian War had begun.
Agree to sell goods on credit to other countries.

After several years of small, armed conflicts and ambushes between Ecuadorian and Peruvian border posts, Perú decided to declare war on Ecuador in order to gain control of the Amazonian lands beyond the Marañón river.  Ecuador was unprepared to meet the Peruvian invasion.  The Ecuadorian president's fear of being left unprotected from his political opponents led him to keep the nation's best fighting forces in Quito.\n When the much larger Peruvian army moved quickly into the southern coastal province of El Oro, the fewer than 1,800 Ecuadorian troops in the area lacked sufficient air cover, and were able to offer only limited resistance.  Peruvian forces also moved into the disputed Amazonian territory without significant opposition.

The Lend-Lease Agreements were arrangements for the transfer of war supplies, including food, machinery, and services, to nations whose defence was considered vital to the defence of the United States in World War II.  The Lend-Lease Act, passed in 1941 by the U.S. Congress, gave the President power to sell, transfer, lend or lease such war materials.  The President was directed to set the terms for aid repayment to be "in kind or property" or any other direct or indirect benefit which the President deems satisfactory."\n Harry L. Hopkins was appointed in March", 1941 to administer lend-lease.  He was replaced in July by Edward R. Stettinius, Jr., who headed the Office of Lend-Lease Administration, set up in Oct., 1941.  In Sept. 1943, lend-lease was incorporated into the Foreign Economic Administration under Leo T. Crowley.  In Sept. 1945, it was transferred to the Dept. of State.\n Lend-lease was originally intended for China and countries of the British Empire.  In Nov.,1941, the USSR was included, and by the end of the war practically all the allies of the United States had been declared eligible for lend-lease aid.  Although not all requested or received it, lend-lease agreements were signed with numerous countries.

Since first ironclad warships all countries tried their best to produce high quality steel suited for huge armour plates needed for building bigger and bigger warships. Every major naval country came up with slightly different idea. Japanese version of vickers steel used copper instead of nickel simply because nickel shortages. USN focused on Special Treatment Steel which was good as both armour and structural steel."Only" downside was the cost of that steel which was the reason why only USA used it on all its ships build after 1930. Royal Navy and Kriegsmarine used Krupp Cemented Steel which was probably best armour steel available at the time, but limited its usage to capital ships and carriers. *AI JAP, GER, USA, ENG will follow historical path here. Our enemies caused us more problems than our staff predicted. Our units were defeated by combination of enemy tactical and strategical superiority, detailed planning and incredibly effective artillery support. All those caused our brightest generals to rethink their way of handling battles. It was requested to use gathered information and experience and incorporate "borrowed" ideas into our doctrine. On the other hand other generals, believe that we should stick to our, in their opinion, still superior doctrine and ignore different approaches to warfare.
We need to adapt if we want to survive. Learn §BGrand Battle Plan§b basics!

Some of our soldiers that survived this horrible massacre reported that our enemy was far superior in overwhelming our troops with all kinds of firepower. Starting with small arms, mortars and ending on heavy artillery, mechanized troops and tanks. What's worse our enemy wasn't mindlessly sending more and more guns at us. It was well organized battle with all troops knowing when to attack, counterattack or defend. They had firepower advantage and they knew how to use it as best as possible. It is in our best interest to try to simulate that even on a basic level if we want to survive this war.
We need to adapt if we want to survive. Learn §BSuperior Firepower§b basics!

When the first shock passed clear picture of what happened appeared. Something that for frontline soldiers looked like neverending, mindless hordes of infantry and tanks was in fact decently planned and executed operation combining all available troop types. And not only on tiny part of the front, but in multiple places. Something that we thought was accidental, is in fact effective strategy with pre-planned points of concentrated attacks supported by tremendous ammounts of artillery, mobile troops and planes. This and sheer numbers of enemy forces simply overpowered our troops. We have a chance now to fix issues with our own army and tactics by learning from our enemies. It will be close to impossible to adapt key concepts of this doctrine for our needs but some might be useful.
We need to adapt if we want to survive. Learn §BDeep Battle Plan§b basics!

For the past two decades our army tried more or less successfully to use mobile troops and tanks. We had our ideas. Same as other armies, but what happened just now proved that one idea was far superior than others. Our troops were overrun before full picture of what's going on even reached HQ. Speed, aggressiveness, level of coordination between air and ground units - it's everything our army should aspire to. With this in mind we need to use every possible piece of information to somehow, even if not fully, replicate those tactics. With growing importance of tanks and mobile troops it is necessary for us to not stay behind.
We need to adapt if we want to survive. Learn §BBlitzkrieg§b basics!

Despite our victory we can't allow ourselves to grow complacent. We've won, but it was bloody, gruesome battle that could've been finished earlier if we could avoid few mistakes that were made on various stages of both planning and execution - something that our enemy did almost perfectly. Despite the fact that his plan seemed perfect we need to find its weak spots and if possible use some of his ideas against him in the future. Hopefuly by combining our expertise and lesson from this horrible defeat we will be able to avoid such disasters in upcoming battles.
Our doctrine needs to evolve! Learn §BGrand Battle Plan§b basics!

We've won, but the price we had to pay is devastating. Our troops were decimated by enemy artillery, mobile troops appearing out of nowhere and by hail of gunfire available to every platoon in opposing army. This is lesson that we cannot ignore. We need to do our best to analyze everything that happened starting with even smallest firefights, combat patrols, finishing on army level and general ideas about how our enemy sees warfare. We need to learn and adapt so next time our victory won't require thousands to sacrifice their lives.
Our doctrine needs to evolve! Learn §BSuperior Firepower§b basics!

Somehow our soldiers managed to carve through that seemingly endless waves of enemy soldiers and tanks. Victory is ours, but it's definitely not a day to celebrate. Our losses are far too high to call that true victory. Our units are disorganized and need reinforcements and some rest. Our enemy, despite defeat managed to use his strengths to slow down our progress. We need to make sure that situation like that never happens. Our staff needs to adjust their ideas to suit our enemy. To allow us to overcome the fact that he's ferocious, tireless and knows exactly how to make us pay dearly for each step forward.
Our doctrine needs to evolve! Learn §BDeep Battle Doctrine§b basics!

It's over. One battle that seemed to last for an eternity. With inhuman determination, despite heavy losses our troops managed to slow down and eventualy push back enemy armored units. We're no longer in danger of being cut off from the rest of our army. Despite our victory, our generals are confident that some aspects and ideas used by our enemy can be successfully incorporated into our army. Having more options to use in upcoming battles is something that might game changer in terms of outcome of the entire war.
Our doctrine needs to evolve! Learn §BBlitzkrieg§b basics!

The Zaibatsus ("Financial Clique") are the major business conglomerates that operate in Imperial Japan, such as Mitsubishi or Yasuda. Their power within our Empire is both a strength and a weakness, their ability to propel our industrial progress has turned Japan into a powerful industrial country, but their deep influence within our political system has at times proven to bring instability and uncertainty. In this new phase of expansion of our Empire it's time to decide how we should handle the Zaibatsus

The IJA and the IJN have been embroiled in a long-term discord since the times of the Meji period. While this rivalry often compels each side to work hard to be better than the other, it also often leads to assassinations and lack of coordination. Nevertheless both factions have shown their military ambitions and will prove crucial for the future of Japan.\n\nEvery year we can decide to favor the IJA or the IJN to expand them faster or get both to work on their respective airforces.

The puppet state of Manchukuo was created following the Japanese invasion of Manchuria and the need to retain control over it. Holding many of the resources that homeland Japan desperately needed, the region of Manchuria will prove to be of most use for Japan's economy. Being formally governed by the the last emperor of China, Puyi, Manchukuo holds some legitimacy that a direct Japanese rule won't provide, however it limits the range of control we can assert over it. We must now decide if we wish to continue the Manchurian project and further invest into Manchuria through Manchukuo or take direct control over it and develop it more carefully but have to deal with more insurgency.

To safeguard the development of Manchuria we need Manchukuo to be able to protect itself from external and internal threats. Providing them with some of our volunteers and officers will help ensure our investments will be secure. Having our officers in the frontline of dealing with Chinese insurgency in Manchuria will also provide us with important knowledge on how to deal with similar situations ourselves in the future. We can choose to send a small contigent or estabilish a continuous connection with their counterinsurgency operations.
Cooperating with counterinsurgency operations in Manchukuo
Learning from counterinsurgency operations in Manchukuo

The Dowa Automobile Company was founded in 1934 as a joint venture of the South Manchurian Railway Company, the government of Manchukuo and several Japanese companies. The need for increased motorization spurred the Kwantung Army to develop heavy industry for the construction of trucks and automobiles which came to be by the creation of Dowa, assisted by Isuzu and an increasing support of local sub-suppliers.

The Manchuria Airplane Manufacturing Company was estabilished in 1938 as a subsidiary of the Nakajima Aircraft Company of Japan. It has the capacity to produce light aircraft and some medium aircraft and will add to the production of Nakajima's single engine aircraft models as well as some twin engine models from Kawasaki and Mitsubishi.

With the proven success of our investments in Manchuria, some entrepreneurs and technocrats like Yoshisuke Aikawa, founder of Nissan, are voicing increasing support for the creation of the Manchukuo Industrial Development Company, a centralized entity to manage and further expand the industry of Manchukuo. Aikawa is certain this investment will bring Manchukuo's resource production to new heights and has promised an expansion of the Showa Steel Works production soon after his proposal is approved. We can choose to give this new entity financial help, industrial help or both for an even stronger result.
Loans and Tax Exemptions for Mangyo

Following the creation of the Mangyo(Manchurian Industrial Development Company) and as promised by Aikawa, the Showa Steel Works has been greatly expanded and is now on course to become one of the largest iron and steel centers of the world.

Mangyo(Manchurian Industrial Development Company) has since it's creation been doing everything to improve the efficiency of our steel mills in Machuria. With warmer relations between Germany and Japan, Mangyo decided to license the Krupp-Renn process from German steel markers and send people to Germany for training in this method. With the training process complete, Krupp has sent the equipment which promises to greatly increase the steel production of the Showa Steel Works.

One of Japan's first key investments in Manchuria was the creation of the Manchukuo National Railway and it's expansion. Merging existing railway companies, finishing existing construction plans and connecting detached lines has been a long process, occupying most of the companies existence. We are now in the final stage of this process and starting to collect the results of our investments in a significant increase in Manchukuo's resource output. However there are still some minor connections to complete and the large disparity between the gauge of our new connections and the North Manchuria Railway Bureau built by the Soviets to fix. We must now choose to complete this final investment or settle for what we have.

While most of Manchuria is already well connected by rail, the southeast near northeast Korea remains a hole in our rail network, separating Korean railways from the Manchukuo National Railway. This doesn't let us take full advantage of some of the coal deposits in the region and poses a logistical problem if war with Soviet Union breaks out. The Kwantung Army has been pushing for the idea of creating the East Manchuria Railway here and the time has come for us to make a decision on the matter.

The Nagoya Pan-Pacific Peace Exposition is to be held during the next couple of months, it's intended to promote industry, transportation, education, science, construction, architecture, social welfare, tourism, fine arts and crafts. Most countries in the Pacific will be participating and it's an important oportunity to bolster our foreign relations. While prince Higashikuni Naruhiko intends for this exposition to showcase the Nagoya region as an industrial and cultural center of the empire, many members of the IJA object to the idea of a completely peaceful exposition. We can either stay true to the name of the event and improve our foreign relations or give the IJA a hall for a display of force.

The Yagi-Uda antenna was invented in 1926 by Shintaro Uda and Hidetsugu Yagi of the Tohoku Imperial University. Its concept has attracted a lot of interest due to its simplicity and directionality, some aviation engineers in our armed forces even think it could be used as an individual radar for aircraft in the future. Unfortunately, the IJA and the IJN are less than convinced and they oppose any sort of interference forcing them to make use of this invention.

In a recent operation our troops have captured a team of enemy Radar Technicians with notes on something called the "yagi antenna". Embarassingly, our own intelligence officers didn't recognize it at first but this is the invention of a Japanese professor from 1926. This antenna is used by enemy aircraft for radar search and has been giving the enemy an edge in our engagements, it's about time we use our own technology...
Introducing Yagi-Uda Antenna into the Military

On the 11th of March 1936, an army of less than 100 Mongolian soldiers with six Soviet advisors invaded the disputed village of Tauran, where they defeated the Manchurian defenders. Later that same day the Imperial Japanese Army with some Manchurian volunteers launched an attack to retake the village. The Japanese forces consisted of ten armored vehicles and dozens of warplanes, which bombed the village overnight. The next morning the Japanese launched their ground assault with a force of more than 400 soldiers and a few tanks. The Mongolians were slaughtered and barely did any damage to the Japanese as they were forced to retreat. A quarter of their initial force was killed along with two officers and their commander. Three Soviet advisors were also killed, creating tensions between both nations.

On the 19th of June 1937 three Soviet gunboats (Type 1124 BKA "armoured cutters") crossed the center line of the Amur river, unloaded twenty troops and occupied Kanchazu Island. On June 20, 17 Manchurian police and soldiers were sent to investigate the border intrusion. On the morning of June 30, IJA soldiers from the 49th Regiment of the 1st Division led by Colonel Mihara Kanae launched a prolonged attack against the Soviets. Sheeling from Japanese forces sank the Soviet lead gunboat and damaged the other two leading to the Soviet evacuation of the Kanchazu island. Shigemitsu Mamoru, the Japanese ambassador to the Soviet Union, met with Commissar of Foreign Affairs Maxim Litvinov on June 29 to discuss the turn of events.

With the stabilization of the 2nd Sino-Japanese War, the Imperial General Headquarters now needs to begin planning the next expansion target. For decades the IJA and the IJN have defended opposing doctrines to solve Japan's resource problems.

The IJA defends Hokushin-ron, Northern Expansion Doctrine, an attack on the Soviet Union to take hold of the natural resources of Siberia. While the success of the Russo-Japanese War is still fresh in the mind so are the failures of the recent border disputes with the Soviet Union.

The IJN defends Nanshin-ron, Southern Expansion Doctrine, an attack on the resource rich areas of Southeast Asia. While the riches of the East Indies are considerably more valuable and less defended than the Soviet Union, any movement in the Pacific is sure to raise the attention of the United States of America. While we may start a potential conflict better prepared it is unclear how long the advantage can be mantained due to the industrial difference between us and the USA. With this in mind, some in the Navy General Staff have been circulating the idea of a surprise strike on the US Pacific fleet in order to bring more time for the IJN to fulfill its goals. If we instead choose to attack the Allies alone early it is clear the United States will intevene within a few months and we will lose any opportunity for a surprise attack on them...

Genrikh Lyushkov, a member of the NKVD has entered into contact with authorities in Manchukuo with the intention to defect. He has promissed to bring with him valuable documents about Soviet military strength in the region which are sure to help us in a potential conflict with them in the coming years.

The 2nd Naval Armaments Supplement Programme is underway and the construction of the Soryu and Hiryu aircraft carriers is coming together. The Tone-class heavy cruisers, Tone and Chikuma, are also under construction and should be complete on schedule. Along with them, the submarine support ship Takasaki is under conversion into the Zuiho light aircraft carrier. In addition to this, several destroyers and torpedo boats are under construction as well as a few long range submarines.

With the break out of war with Japan it is clear that one of their primary goals is to take control of oil rich East Indies. Most of our military advisors think we won't be able to defend them against the Japanese invasion and are suggesting to damage oil facilities in the region as much as we can before they fall into the hands of the enemy. This process will take up to two weeks to complete, we must hold what we can until then.
We managed to destroy some oil facilities in the East Indies in time before the Japanese took hold of them, any province that we still hold will suffer this effect.

We have received reports that the Allies are planning to damage oil facilities in the East Indies as much as they can before we can take control over them, we must hurry with our invasion plans. Intelligence suggests we have at most two weeks before the Allies can complete this operation.
The Allies have managed to destroy some oil facilities in the East Indies. Any province with oil facilities still held by them is surely severely damaged.

The Viet Minh was formed in Nanjing, China, in 1936 with the goal of liberating Vietnam from the French Empire. While under French control, they used guerrilla tactics to harass French military in the area and disrupt industry and mines. With Indochina now under our control, the Viet Minh have shown they will continue their insurgency against our occupation.
The Viet Minh have launched several uprisings in the regions of Tonkin, Annam and Cochinchina.

With the break out of war with Japan an invasion of our homeland is a serious concern. To protect against this menace some of our advisors are suggesting obsolete pre-WW1 and WW1 field guns could be deployed for coastal defence.
Deploying obsolete field guns for coastal defense

The Nanping Coal mines in China hold a considerable amount of coal but are still relatively underdeveloped. Investing into the mines and the rail connection to the port of Fuzhou is a great opportunity to expand its production. A police station will also be set up near the mines to quell unrest

Since the break out of the Second Sino-Japanese War, public opinion in Australia opposed trade relations with Japan. This culminated in the Dalfram dispute during which, in several instances, wharf labourers refused to load iron destined to Japan. The Australian Council of Trade Unions called for a boycott of Japanese goods and an embargo on the export of iron to Japan in response to the Japanese aggression. Eventually the Australian government approved a ban on all iron export to Japan.
After outstanding sea trials during the last month it is finally that far\n\nKMS Bismarck is launched and ready for duty.
With it's relatively small industrial base Canada has been able to maintan two well equiped Infantry Divisions in 1936. \n 'Old Red Patch' and the 2nd Division are ready for your orders!
We have prepared some informative events for some new and old mechanics of the mod.\nWe recommend you read them for your first playthrough of this version.

In BlackICE, unit training level has a permanent effect on the unit performance.\nUnits trained with basic training law will always perform as such, even if the law is changed. To increase their training level they have to be properly retrained with the new training law in place. \nCombat Experience is properly distinguished from training level and can only be obtained through combat. The training level impacts the unit's stats while combat experience has a direct impact on combat as a modifier. The effect of each level of training laws can be seen in the Training folder of the Technology screen. Combinations of training and conscription laws also trigger certain effects which can be checked in Triggered Modifiers

In BlackICE, ministers don't only give flat effects, but they are now also responsible for your country's civilian and war economy. Depending on your choice of ministers for each position you will gain different types of buildings from time to time which are not normally buildable. The selected national focus that year will also impact how often the bonus is gained.

Due to game engine limitations, event spawned units are spawned directly on the map instead of in the production queue. Your country will suffer an IC penalty which is scaled with your base IC and on par (generally a little lower) with the IC cost of the unit.
Sometimes alot of units become available at the same time. Taking all of them at the same time could cripple your economy, so consider waiting a bit if you are already low on IC.

As a reminder: Units that will be removed by events will have coloured names.

In BlackICE, regular transport ships can not be used to launch naval invasions. This can only be achieved by auxilliary vessels or landing/assault ships.\nLanding/assault ships can be researched, while auxilliary vessels can be requisitioned once a year when at war. These ships represent a wide variety of civilian ships, from fishing boats to merchant ships, as such they are much more fragile and slower than military vessels. The AI is allowed to perform naval invasions with regular transport ships.

In BlackICE, energy to oil conversion(Coal Liquefaction) is disabled by default, in real life this process was very complicated and not readily available at the industrial scale. However, when at war, energy to oil can be activated through Autarky events. Additionally, nations which had invested heavily into these technologies, such as Germany, will have access to it through certain events before war breaks out. The conversion ratio can be improved as usual through a technology in the Industry tab, after the process is activated.

In BlackICE, a new type of minister, the Science Minister, provides countries with specific boosts to their research based on their speciality. Theoretical Scientists provide no direct benefits but will eventually build Research Centers, Research Specialists provide direct bonus to research but do not build new Research Centers, Technical Specialists provide bonus do available leadership instead of directly to research. The remaining types are specialists in specific areas and will passively produce technological progress in their area. Specialist Science Ministers will also ask for a potential increase in budget through an event which allows them to progress in their speciality faster.
